Fragment of a later Roman Latin inscription
Remains of two evenly spaced lines of Latin letters; use of double-dot interpuncts.

Regularly cut letters of moderate width module (rectangular but not narrow). Vertical strokes of A and N in line 2 do not fully join; A has broken bar. Interpuncts formed of double vertical drilled holes.
467 CE or 538 CE, depending on the consular identification (Ferrua)

l.2 quae
Three even and equal lines of text, carefully set out, with vacats above and below.

Orsi attributed it to the Norman period, Ferrua (1989) suggested the Saracen period due to the name Taric, and Manganaro suggests Gothic, each lowering the date therefore, which seems to belong in late antiquity, perhaps later 6th century CE, or earlier 7th century CE, dated by indiction (14th).

l.3 reg., orig. univera | l.4 reg., orig. que
Four lines of Latin letters, with vacat below; the trace of a letter below line 3 respects the exact distances between the other lines. Text runs at a slightly offset angle to the two edges.
Thin v-cut with neat serfis, use of supralines, ligatures, and a fairly narrow module. Very regular letters in height. G has a detached hook.
Letter types, esp. the G, sugg. c. 200 CE (so Manganaro; Ferrua dates later)

Six densely ordered lines of neat Greek letters; staurogram to left of lines 3-4.
Neatly v-cut Greek letters with minimal serifs and some extended strokes. Alpha is tending towards the cursive form. Lunate epsilon and sigma, uncial omega; mu tending to cursive.
Dated to the 25 January 402 CE, by the consulship of Vincentius of 401 (omitting his colleague, Fravitus).
